text: I mean no major license bans commercialization in all forms as most commercialization happens through software as service which is not well captured in the current license framework. Is a hot topic on the EU (especially with the controversies of first seller).

text: A license is a just describing the terms of uses. By default the copyright holder retains all rights so you can say anyone in the world can use it except that bully from high school and that’s perfectly fine.

elements.text: A license is a just describing the terms of uses. By default the copyright holder retains all rights so you can say anyone in the world can use it except that bully from high school and that’s perfectly fine.

text: I think for JuliaRegistries/NonFree we might strongly recommend that the license (even if nonfree) has a SPDX identifier. So if you want noncommercial use, you could use e.g. <https://spdx.org/licenses/CC-BY-NC-ND-4.0.html>, which does have a SPDX identifier

elements.text: I think for JuliaRegistries/NonFree we might strongly recommend that the license (even if nonfree) has a SPDX identifier. So if you want noncommercial use, you could use e.g.
, which does have a SPDX identifier

text: That doesn’t fully stop someone though. They are free to commercialize it through software as service and such which is pretty common.

elements.text: That doesn’t fully stop someone though. They are free to commercialize it through software as service and such which is pretty common.

text: Yeah. There is <https://spdx.org/licenses/SSPL-1.0.html> for that.

elements.text: Yeah. There is
for that.

text: But yeah I agree, for JuliaRegistries/NonFree, while we would *recommend* that users use an SPDX identifier, I don't think we would require it.

elements.text: But yeah I agree, for JuliaRegistries/NonFree, while we would
recommend
that users use an SPDX identifier, I don't think we would require it.

text: So you could just do "all rights reserved" or whatever you want. And it's the responsibility of users that use JuliaRegistries/NonFree to verify the licensing terms of software they use.

elements.text: So you could just do "all rights reserved" or whatever you want. And it's the responsibility of users that use JuliaRegistries/NonFree to verify the licensing terms of software they use.

text: Basically just a marketplace… Contact the copyright holder for permission and access (e.g., get a suitable license agreement).

text: But you still get the convenience of having a registry. And package authors don't need to maintain their own registry.

elements.text: But you still get the convenience of having a registry. And package authors don't need to maintain their own registry.

text: I still think it is probably best for JuliaComputing to handle non-open source packages. I agree that having a marketplace for commercial packages is a good proposal but I don’t think the open source community is the best group to manage it.

elements.text: I still think it is probably best for JuliaComputing to handle non-open source packages. I agree that having a marketplace for commercial packages is a good proposal but I don’t think the open source community is the best group to manage it.

text: Sure, I don't feel strongly either way. As long as we have some registry that anyone can submit commercial packages to

text: I very much think this is not a territory the community should get into. If someone wants to create a registry with non free software, it is super easy for them to do so and they can put whatever rules they want in there.

elements.text: I very much think this is not a territory the community should get into. If someone wants to create a registry with non free software, it is super easy for them to do so and they can put whatever rules they want in there.

text: I don’t use them myself, but I really don’t understand why there seems to be so much opposition here to licenses that are free except for certain commercial uses (e.g. “commons clause”, etc.). That just  seems like an equally justifiable way someone might want to develop and share software, yet it seems to be treated as downright _verboten_? The normal argument that “commercial” is poorly defined does not really strike me as compelling.

elements.text: I don’t use them myself, but I really don’t understand why there seems to be so much opposition here to licenses that are free except for certain commercial uses (e.g. “commons clause”, etc.). That just  seems like an equally justifiable way someone might want to develop and share software, yet it seems to be treated as downright
verboten
? The normal argument that “commercial” is poorly defined does not really strike me as compelling.

text: It's perfectly fine to use those licenses; it's just that we don't accept those licenses in the General registry because those packages are not open source, and we want the General registry to only have open source packages.

elements.text: It's perfectly fine to use those licenses; it's just that we don't accept those licenses in the General registry because those packages are not open source, and we want the General registry to only have open source packages.

text: That's why I think it would be good for someone to make a NonFree registry that does not have the "open source" requirement. I guess it probably won't be the JuliaRegistries organization. But hopefully some other group will pursue it.

elements.text: That's why I think it would be good for someone to make a NonFree registry that does not have the "open source" requirement. I guess it probably won't be the JuliaRegistries organization. But hopefully some other group will pursue it.

text: Oh yeah that point I totally understand, it’s the Kristoffer’s point above that “this is not a territory the community should get into” that I don’t understand

text: I meant that I don't think there should be something that looks "official" and endorsed somehow by the julia community. Of course, every individual is free to do whatever they want.

elements.text: I meant that I don't think there should be something that looks "official" and endorsed somehow by the julia community. Of course, every individual is free to do whatever they want.

text: It is super easy for someone to set up their own registry and provide non-free software (which is a perfectly fine way to distribute software) under whatever terms they like. I don't see how there is anything actionable that needs to happen from the community's p.o.v.

elements.text: It is super easy for someone to set up their own registry and provide non-free software (which is a perfectly fine way to distribute software) under whatever terms they like. I don't see how there is anything actionable that needs to happen from the community's p.o.v.

text: Fair enough, though I think I’m still missing the underlying point about why it would be in your view bad/undesirable for there to be a community-endorsed home for software with restrictions on commercial use
